annotation.Action: Witnesses the overwhelming emotions of other slaves.
Maintains composure despite overwhelming emotions.
Acknowledges the national mood and expresses understanding.
Is offered a job based on his musical talent.
Participates in digging a grave, demonstrating physical capability despite the circumstances.
Participates in work alongside others, indicating camaraderie.
Responds to Fitzgerald with no intrusion, maintaining composure.
Intermingles with the Chickasaws and participates in sharing food and smoke.
Does not take action against Epps' merger offerings, indicating a lack of power in his situation.
Refers to the laborers as 'a team of niggers' when describing who will clear the waterway.
Looks at Patsey as though she were insane, showing some difficulty in fully understanding her despair.
Tears up a letter he started writing without much thought, showing a moment of internal conflict or hesitation.
Submits to Tibeats' unreasonable demands without open confrontation, agreeing to follow orders despite disagreement.
Fights desperately against his chains despite pain and exhaustion.
Does not retaliate or escalate conflict despite verbal abuse and provocation from Tibeats.
Offers reassurance to Celeste by telling her none will come after her in the swamps.
Plays violin vigorously and skillfully at a social gathering, earning enthusiastic applause and personal thanks from attendees of a different race.
Dismisses Patsey's deep despair as melancholia, questions her understanding of her own suffering.
Shares a meaningful, silent moment of mutual respect and gratitude with Bass despite the constraints of their situation.
Helps dump Robert's body overboard, calmly watches the body sink.
Encourages Anne to jump into his arms, confidently assuring her he will catch her.
Looks around the Ford house carefully upon regaining consciousness, noting the contrast in surroundings.
Shares a vulnerable moment admitting people only see her as 'scary', softening her tone.
Voluntarily stands up to read a deeply personal and emotionally vulnerable poem aloud in front of the class, despite initial hesitation and others' reluctance.
Wins the game and high fives the others, who are scared of her.
Sneaks a glance at Patrick and feels miffed when he looks away, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Does not respond or react when Bianca asks her to turn down the music, showing a deliberate choice to maintain control over her environment.
Admits to Mandella that she is not confident the fake ID will work ('No fear' said ironically), showing awareness of the situation's difficulty.
